question: A 03
sols_html:
Consider connecting the two vectors into a right triangle similar the picture to the right. To get the component of \(\mathbf{x}\) onto \(\mathbf{y}\), we follow like in the picture and take,

\[\begin{aligned} \textrm{proj}_\mathbf{y}\mathbf{x}=|\mathbf{x}|\cos(\theta)\hat{\mathbf{y}}\end{aligned}\]


where \(\theta\) is the angle between the vectors \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(\mathbf{y}\) and \(\hat{\mathbf{y}}\) is a unit vector in the direction of \(\mathbf{y}\). We can rewrite \(\cos(\theta)\) in terms of the dot (scalar) product as,

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(\theta)=\frac{\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{y}}{|\mathbf{x}||\mathbf{y}|}.\end{aligned}\]


Therefore, the projection of \(\mathbf{x}\) onto \(\mathbf{y}\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \textrm{proj}_\mathbf{y}\mathbf{x}=\frac{\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{y}}{|\mathbf{y}|}\hat{\mathbf{y}}=\frac{\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{y}}{|\mathbf{y}|^2}\mathbf{y}\end{aligned}\]


where we have recognized that

\[\begin{aligned} \hat{\mathbf{y}}=\frac{\mathbf{y}}{|\mathbf{y}|}.\end{aligned}\]


Computing the dot product we get,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{y}=0-3+2=-1\end{aligned}\]


and for the magnitude of \(\mathbf{y}\),

\[\begin{aligned} |\mathbf{y}|=\sqrt{1^2+1^2+1^2}=\sqrt{3}.\end{aligned}\]


Therefore we get that the projection of \(\mathbf{x}\) onto \(\mathbf{y}\) is,

\[\begin{aligned} \textrm{proj}_\mathbf{y}\mathbf{x}=\frac{\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{y}}{|\mathbf{y}|^2}\mathbf{y}=-\frac{1}{3}\mathbf{y}=\left[-\frac{1}{3},-\frac{1}{3},-\frac{1}{3}\right].\end{aligned}\]

Given the vectors

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}&=[0,-3,2]\\ \mathbf{y}&=[1,1,1]\end{aligned}\]

Compute the projection of x onto the direction of y.
